body: MEADE-Reverend Garvey G. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the parochial vicar of Good Shepherd Church, 1950 Batchelder Street, Brooklyn, on November 13, 1999. Reposing in Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, Wednesday, November 17, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 p.m., and Thursday, November 18, from 2 to 5 p.m. Mass of
title: Paid Notice: Deaths MEADE, REVEREND GARVEY G.

body: A retired police sergeant broke up an armed robbery attempt in Brooklyn early yesterday and shot one of the suspects, the police said. The former sergeant, Eugene Assencao, who retired from the Housing Police in 1988, was driving along Nostrand Avenue in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn shortly after 1 A.M. when he saw three men with guns
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Former Sergeant Stops Store Holdup, Police Say

body: COYLE-Matthew J. On August 10th, 1999. Devoted husband of Ann (nee O'Donnell). Beloved father of Kathleen, Joann, Maryann Donahue & Patricia CoyleKane. Loving brother of Michael. Cherished grandfather of Michaela Donahue. Matthew was a proud member of the NYPD, serving as Deputy Inspector of Midtown North. Funeral Saturday, 8:30 AM, from the Marine
title: Paid Notice: Deaths COYLE, MATTHEW J.

body: When a skater pulls a handplant on a halfpipe (translation, if needed: the move pictured, but performed upside down on the precipice of a curved ramp), the graphic design on the underside of the board is briefly exposed. This design may seem arbitrary, but to the skater, it may be a crucial expression of identity. Such graphics are the focus of
title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Art Under Foot (the Skater's, That Is)

body: Theater ''GOLLY GEE WHIZ!,'' a musical set in 1939 in a town called Happyville, where the teen-agers decide to boost the economy by putting on a show, could have been pure saccharin. Instead, the show is a funny spoof, thanks to the authors, Eric Rockwell and Joanne Bogart, the director and choreographer, Cynthia Thole, and the spirited
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Recently opened, the 8,830-square-foot Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth is built around rock samples and multimedia displays that explain how the Earth works. Highlights include 168 specimens and 11 large-scale models of rock formations, video stations
title: SPARE TIMES

body: When Chris Ricciardi and his fellow archeologists found two glass eggs while excavating the grounds of the Hendrik I. Lott House in Marine Park, which was a family farm in the 18th century, they were clueless. Mr. Ricciardi, a graduate student and a director of the Lott House Archaeological Project, listed the glass eggs as a mystery object on one
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE; The Dirt on a Dig

body: A 32-year-old man was shot dead behind the wheel of his car in Brooklyn early yesterday after what the police called a minor dispute over double parking. The victim, Chun-Man Sze of Bensonhurst, was shot once in the chest by the passenger of a dark-colored Jeep Cherokee, the police said. Mr. Sze was returning from a fishing trip on Long Island
title: Brooklyn Man Is Fatally Shot in His Car in a Dispute Over Parking

body: Gerritsen Beach doesn't have the name recognition of Borough Park, Flatbush or Coney Island, but this tiny Brooklyn neighborhood on a peninsula between Sheepshead Bay and Marine Park is the star of a Web site called Gerritsen Memories. Marret Kauffner started the site last summer as a place for Kauffner family memories, with a genealogical tree and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ONLINE; Going Back Hoe

body: ''La Boheme'' begins with two penniless young men, a painter and a poet, in a claptrap Paris garret on a chilly Christmas Eve in the early 1830's complaining to each other about how cold they are. Not the most likely story for a sticky June night in New York City. But on Tuesday on the Great Lawn in Central Park, there stood the tenor Marcello
title: OPERA REVIEW; Suspending Disbelief Gladly for 'Boheme' in Central Park

body: WALLACE-Helen Rose (nee Henderson), on May 30, 1999 in her 81st year. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, she was devoted wife, mother, grandmother, daughter, sister, aunt and friend. Beloved wife of the late Arthur M. (Ret. Battalion Chief, FDNY). Loving mother of seventeen children: Mary Compton, Michael, Margaret Brady, Helen Welling, Patricia
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WALLACE, HELEN ROSE (NEE HENDERSON)

body: Much has been made of the fact that British culture has of late been flooding these shores with almost colonial aplomb. Just look at Broadway, the argument goes: it's British; British; British; ''Cats''; British, British. (Come to think of it, ''Cats'' is British, too.) British film, too, seems to be everywhere, from variations on Shakespeare to
title: The British Invasion? Surrender

body: To the Editor: Your article ''In All 5 Boroughs, a Robust Market'' [March 28] states that housing in the 11229 section of Brooklyn (Sheepshead Bay, Gerritsen Beach) has experienced a ''more than 12 percent'' rise in home sale prices this past year. The writer might wish to pay some attention to the anomaly of co-op apartment sales prices in the
title: Co-op Prices In ZIP Code 11229

body: Calling New York City's limited crackdown on unleashed dogs a success, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday that the program would be expanded to several parks around the city. Though the initial crackdown focused on Riverside and Central Parks in Manhattan, the targets this time will include several parks that are outside Manhattan:
title: City to Expand Its Crackdown on Dogs

body: Neighbors of Floyd Bennett Field, where the Federal Aviation Administration plans to erect a $6 million radar tower, say they intend to keep fighting the project. On Monday, the F.A.A. announced that it would put up the radar on a 1.8-acre strip of land that is inside the Gateway National Recreation Area but controlled by the Federal Department of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MARINE PARK; A Planned Radar Tower Has Residents on a Fight Path

body: AN arc of gray seagulls banked against a cold gust of wind and wheeled high above Brighton Beach toward the Atlantic Ocean. Sofia Garber followed the birds with her big blue eyes and pulled the fur collar of her coat to her cheeks. Standing on an expanse of boardwalk between a line of apartment buildings and the sand, Ms. Garber, 51, reflected on
title: From Brighton Beach to America; The Wave of Immigrants Began 25 Years Ago. Soon Russian Filled the Streets. Now, the Tide Is Ebbing.

body: SCHIOTIS-Claire D. (nee Keenan). On February 14, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph (Ret. NYPD). Loving mother of Louise Feeley, Helen Kennedy, Catherine A. Lafferty and the late James (FDNY). Cherished grandmother of Susan, Brendan, and Joseph Feeley, Stacie, Michael, Christopher and Katherine Schiotis, Meghan, Daniel and Erin Kennedy and Brian
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHIOTIS, CLAIRE D.

body: As a young man growing up in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, Peter Fay kept to himself. At home, he was frightened of his father. At school, he was terrified that if he spoke up, other students would think him an oddball. During family gatherings, he sat at the table in silence, imagining terrible repercussions if he opened his mouth. Mr. Fay,
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Fears, and the World of Work

title: Paid Notice: Deaths BRICKFIELD, FRANCIS X.
